conclusion: The problem involves two hemispheres A and B with equal radii and masses m and 2m respectively. Hemisphere B is smooth, and there is friction between hemisphere A and the left wall. The angle between the line joining the centers of the two hemispheres and the horizontal is 30°.
The task is to calculate the dynamic friction coefficient between hemisphere A and the left wall, given that the maximum static friction equals the sliding friction force.
The friction between hemisphere A and the left wall is static friction, and the friction between hemisphere A and hemisphere B is sliding friction.
The direction of the sliding friction force between hemisphere A and hemisphere B is horizontally to the right.
The direction of the static friction force between hemisphere A and the left wall is horizontally to the left.
In the diagram, hemisphere A is in contact with the left wall, and hemisphere B is to the right of hemisphere A. The line joining their centers makes a 30° angle with the horizontal.
From the diagram, the forces acting on hemisphere A include the static friction force from the wall, the sliding friction force from hemisphere B, and gravitational force.
The maximum static friction force between hemisphere A and the wall is equal to the sliding friction force between hemisphere A and hemisphere B.
The maximum static friction force between hemisphere A and the wall is directed horizontally to the right.
